ROW.Description: Documentation on topic
The names of all objects in the search list matching the regular expression 'topic' the regular expression 'topic'
Database x to the R search path; x can be a list, data frame, or R data file created with save. Use search() to show the search path
x from the R search path; x can be a name or character string of an object previously attached or a package
Show files in the current directory
Examples of command
Help with (e.g.) package mva
Documentation on topic
Search the help system
Start the HTML version of help
Load add-on packages; library(help=x) lists datasets and functions in package x
Show objects in the search path; specify pat='pat' to search on a pattern
str() for each variable in the search path
Shows S3 methods of a
Lists all the methods to handle objects of class a
Set or examine many global options; common ones: width, digits, error
Display the internal structure of an R object
Gives a 'summary' of a, usually a statistical summary but it is generic meaning it has different operations for different classes of a
Array with data x; specify dimensions like dim=c(3,4,2); elements of x recycle if x is not long enough
Generic function to combine arguments with the default forming a vector; with recursive=TRUE descends through lists combining all elements into one vector
Idem rbind(...) by columns
Create a data frame of the named or unnamed arguments; data.frame(v=1:4, ch=c('a', 'b', 'c', 'd'), n=10); shorter vectors are recycled to the length of the longest
A data frame from all combinations of the supplied vectors or factors
Encodes a vector x as a factor
Generates a sequence; ':' has operator priority; 1:4 + 1 is '2, 3, 4, 5'
Generate levels (factors) by specifying the pattern of their levels; k is the number of levels, and n is the number of replications
Create a list of the named or unnamed arguments; list(a=c(1, 2), b='hi', c=3i);
Matrix; elements of x recycle
Combine arguments by rows for matrices, data frames, and others
Replicate x times; use 'each=' to repeat 'each' element of x each times; rep(c(1, 2, 3), 2) is 1 2 3 1 2 3; rep(c(1, 2, 3), each=2) is 1 1 2 2 3 3
Generates 1, 2, ..., length(x); useful for for loops
Generates a sequence 'by=' specifies increment; 'length=' specifies desired length
Loads specified data sets
Load the datasets written with save
Idem read.table(file), but with defaults set for reading comma-delimited files
Idem read.table(file), but with defaults set for reading tab-delimited files
Read a table of fixed width formatted data into a 'data.frame'; widths is an integer vector, giving the widths of the fixed-width fields

Reads a file in table format and creates a data frame from it; the default separator sep=' ' is any whitespace; use header=TRUE to read the first line as a header of column names; use as.is=TRUE to prevent character vectors from being converted to factors; use comment.char=' ' to prevent '#' from being interpreted as a comment; use skip=n to skip n lines before reading data; see the help for options on row naming, NA treatment, and others
Read a spreadsheet content from clipboard
Saves the specified objects (...) in the XDR platformindependent binary format
Saves all objects
Writes object to fileName
Writes a table

Prints x after converting to a data frame; if quote is TRUE, character or factor columns are surrounded by quotes (' '); sep is the field separator; eol is the end-of-line separator; na is the string for missing values; use col.names=NA to add a blank column header to get the column headers aligned correctly for spreadsheet input
Computes the combinations of k events among n repetitions=n!/[(n-k)!k!]
Divides x into intervals (factors); breaks is the number of cut intervals or a vector of cut points
Returns a vector of the same length than x with the elements of x which are in y (NA otherwise)
Returns an error message if x contains at least one NA
Suppresses the observations with missing data (NA) (suppresses the corresponding line if x is a matrix or a data frame)
Table entries as fraction of marginal table
Reverses the elements of x
Resample randomly and without replacement size elements in the vector x, the option replace=TRUE allows to resample with replacement
Sorts the elements of x in increasing order; to sort in decreasing order: rev(sort(x))
Returns a selection of x with respect to criteria (..., typically comparisons); if x is a data frame, the option select gives the variables to be kept or dropped using a minus sign
Returns a table with the numbers of the differents values of x (typically for integers or factors)
If x is a vector or a data frame, returns a similar object but with the duplicate elements suppressed
Returns a vector of the indices of x if the comparison operation is true (TRUE), in this example the values of i for which x[i]==a (the argument of this function must be a variable of mode logical)
Returns the index of the greatest element of x
Returns the index of the smallest element of x

Convert to the respective class; format(dt) converts to a string representation. The default string format is '2001-02-21'. These accept a second argument to specify a format for conversion. Some common formats are: %a, %A Abbreviated and full weekday name; %b, %B Abbreviated and full month name; %d Day of the month (01-31); %H Hours (00-23); %I Hours (01-12); %j Day of year (001-366); %m Month (01-12); %M Minute (00-59); %p AM/PM indicator; %S Second as decimal number (00-61); %U Week (00-53); the first Sunday as day 1 of week 1; %w Weekday (0-6, Sunday is 0); %W Week (00-53); the first Monday as day 1 of week 1; %y Year without century (00-99). Don't use; %Y Year with century; %z (output only.) Offset from Greenwich; -0800 is 8 hours west of; %Z (output only.) Time zone as a character string (empty if not available)

Convert to the respective class; format(dt) converts to a string representation. The default string format is '2001-02-21'. These accept a second argument to specify a format for conversion. Some common formats are: %a, %A Abbreviated and full weekday name; %b, %B Abbreviated and full month name; %d Day of the month (01-31); %H Hours (00-23); %I Hours (01-12); %j Day of year (001-366); %m Month (01-12); %M Minute (00-59); %p AM/PM indicator; %S Second as decimal number (00-61); %U Week (00-53); the first Sunday as day 1 of week 1; %w Weekday (0-6, Sunday is 0); %W Week (00-53); the first Monday as day 1 of week 1; %y Year without century (00-99). Don't use; %Y Year with century; %z (output only.) Offset from Greenwich; -0800 is 8 hours west of; %Z (output only.) Time zone as a character string (empty if not available)
Negative binomial
Gaussian (normal)
Wilcoxon's statistics
Student (t)
Wilcoxon's statistics
Draws a line of slope b and intercept a
Draws a horizontal line at ordinate y
Draws the regression line given by lm.obj
Draws a vertical line at abcissa x

ROW.Function: arrows(x0, y0, x1, y1, angle=30, code=2)
ROW.Description: Idem segments(x0, y0, x1, y1), but with arrows at points (x0, y0) if code=2, at points (x1, y1) if code=1, or both if code=3; angle controls the angle from the shaft of the arrow to the edge of the arrow head
Adds an axis at the bottom (side=1), on the left (2), at the top (3), or on the right (4); at=vect (optional) gives the abcissa (or ordinates) where tick-marks are drawn
Draw a box around the current plot
Adds the legend at the point (x,y) with the symbols given by legend
Adds lines (the option 'type=' can be used)

Returns the coordinates (x, y) after the user has clicked n times on the plot with the mouse; also draws symbols (type='p') or lines (type='l') with respect to optional graphic parameters (...); by default nothing is drawn (type='n')
Adds text given by text in the margin specified by side (see axis()); line specifies the line from the plotting area
Adds points (the option 'type=' can be used)
Draws a polygon linking the points with coordinates given by x and y
Draws a rectangle which left, right, bottom, and top limits are x1, x2, y1, and y2, respectively
Draws the data x on the x-axis as small vertical lines
Draws lines from points (x0, y0) to points (x1, y1)
Adds text given by labels at coordinates (x, y); a typical use is: plot(x, y, type='n'); text(x, y, names)
Adds a title and optionally a sub-title
Controls text justification (0 left-justified, 0.5 centred, 1 right-justified)
Specifies the colour of the background (ex. : bg='red', bg='blue', . . . the list of the 657 available colours is displayed with colors())
Controls the type of box drawn around the plot, allowed values are: 'o', 'l', '7', 'c', 'u' ou ']' (the box looks like the corresponding character); if bty='n' the box is not drawn

A value controlling the size of texts and symbols with respect to the default; the following parameters have the same control for numbers on the axes, cex.axis, the axis labels, cex.lab, the title, cex.main, and the sub-title, cex.sub

Controls the color of symbols and lines; use color names: 'red', 'blue' see colors() or as '#RRGGBB'; see rgb(), hsv(), gray(), and rainbow(); as for cex there are: col.axis, col.lab, col.main, col.sub
An integer which controls the style of text (1: normal, 2: italics, 3: bold, 4: bold italics); as for cex there are: font.axis, font.lab, font.main, font.sub
An integer which controls the orientation of the axis labels (0: parallel to the axes, 1: horizontal, 2: perpendicular to the axes, 3: vertical)

Controls the type of lines, can be an integer or string (1: 'solid', 2: 'dashed', 3: 'dotted', 4: 'dotdash', 5: 'longdash', 6: 'twodash', or a string of up to eight characters (between '0' and '9') which specifies alternatively the length, in points or pixels, of the drawn elements and the blanks, for example lty='44' will have the same effect than lty=2
A numeric which controls the width of lines, default 1
A vector of 4 numeric values which control the space between the axes and the border of the graph of the form c(bottom, left, top, right), the default values are c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1)
A vector of the form c(nr, nc) which partitions the graphic window as a matrix of nr lines and nc columns, the plots are then drawn in columns
Idem mfcol, but the plots are drawn by row
Controls the type of symbol, either an integer between 1 and 25, or any single character within ' '
An integer which controls the size in points of texts and symbols
A character which specifies the type of the plotting region, 's': square, 'm': maximal
A value which specifies the length of tick-marks on the axes as a fraction of the smallest of the width or height of the plot; if tck=1 a grid is drawn
A value which specifies the length of tick-marks on the axes as a fraction of the height of a line of text (by default tcl=-0.5)
Style of axis interval calculation; default 'r' for an extra space; 'i' for no extra space
If xaxt='n' the x-axis is set but not drawn (useful in conjunction with axis(side=1, ...))
Style of axis interval calculation; default 'r' for an extra space; 'i' for no extra space
If yaxt='n' the y-axis is set but not drawn (useful in conjonction with axis(side=2, ...))
Parameters are common to many plotting functions, if TRUE superposes the plot on the previous one (if it exists)
Cohen-Friendly graph showing the deviations from independence of rows and columns in a two dimensional contingency table
Parameters are common to many plotting functions, if FALSE does not draw the axes and the box
Histogram of the values of x; use horiz=FALSE for horizontal bars
Box-and-whiskers plot
Contour plot (data are interpolated to draw the curves), x and y must be vectors and z must be a matrix so that dim(z)=c(length(x), length(y)) (x and y may be omitted)
Bivariate plot of x and y for each value or interval of values of z
If x is a data frame, plots a Cleveland dot plot (stacked plots line-by-line and column-by-column)
Idem contour(x, y, z), but the areas between the contours are coloured, and a legend of the colours is drawn as well
Visualizes, with quarters of circles, the association between two dichotomous variables for different populations (x must be an array with dim=c(2, 2, k), or a matrix with dim=c(2, 2) if k=1)
Histogram of the frequencies of x
Idem contour(x, y, z), but with colours (actual data are plotted)

If f1 and f2 are factors, plots the means of y (on the y-axis) with respect to the values of f1 (on the x-axis) and of f2 (different curves); the option fun allows to choose the summary statistic of y (by default fun=mean)
Parameters are common to many plotting functions, main title, must be a variable of mode character
Bivariate plot of the first column of x vs. the first one of y, the second one of x vs. the second one of y, etc.
Mosaic graph of the residuals from a log-linear regression of a contingency table
If x is a matrix or a data frame, draws all possible bivariate plots between the columns of x
Idem contour(x, y, z), but in perspective (actual data are plotted)
Circular pie-chart
Plot of the values of x (on the y-axis) ordered on the x-axis
Bivariate plot of x (on the x-axis) and y (on the y-axis)
If x is an object of class 'ts', plot of x with respect to time, x may be multivariate but the series must have the same frequency and dates
Quantiles of x with respect to the values expected under a normal law
Quantiles of y with respect to the quantiles of x
If x is a matrix or a data frame, draws a graph with segments or a star where each row of x is represented by a star and the columns are the lengths of the segments
produces a stem-and-leaf plot of the values in 'x'
Plot of the values of x on a line (an alternative to boxplot() for small sample sizes)
Parameters are common to many plotting functions, sub-title (written in a smaller font)
Idem than plot() but the points with similar coorcoordinates are drawn as flowers which petal number represents the number of points
Draws, at the coordinates given by x and y, symbols (circles, squares, rectangles, stars, thermometres or 'boxplots') which sizes, colours . . . are specified by supplementary arguments
Plot of the (partial) effects of a regression model (mod.obj)
Idem plot.ts(x) but if x is multivariate the series may have different dates and must have the same frequency

Parameters are common to many plotting functions, specifies the type of plot, 'p': points, 'l': lines, 'b': points connected by lines, 'o': id. but the lines are over the points, 'h': vertical lines, 's': steps, the data are represented by the top of the vertical lines, 'S': id. but the data are represented by the bottom of the vertical lines
Parameters are common to many plotting functions, annotates the axes, must be variables of mode character
Parameters are common to many plotting functions, specifies the lower and upper limits of the axes, for example with xlim=c(1, 10) or xlim=range(x)
Parameters are common to many plotting functions, annotates the axes, must be variables of mode character
Parameters are common to many plotting functions, specifies the lower and upper limits of the axes, for example with ylim=c(1, 10) or ylim=range(x)
See ?Devices
Shuts down the specified (default is the current) graphics device; see also dev.cur, dev.set see also dev.cur, dev.set
See ?Devices
See ?Devices
See ?Devices
See ?Devices

Starts the graphics device driver for producing PostScript graphics; use horizontal=FALSE, onefile=FALSE, paper='special' for EPS files; 'family=' specifies the font (AvantGarde, Bookman, Courier, Helvetica, Helvetica-Narrow, NewCenturySchoolbook, Palatino, Times, or ComputerModern); 'width=' and 'height=' specifies the size of the region in inches (for paper='special', these specify the paper size)
Set and view (if called without arguments) default values for the arguments to postscript
Open a graphics window
Open a graphics window
See ?Devices
Histogram of the values of y with respect to those of x
Box-and-whiskers plot
3d scatter plot
Density functions plot
Cleveland dot plot (stacked plots line-by-line and columnby-column)
Histogram of the frequencies of x
Coloured plot of the values of z at the coordinates given by x and y (x, y and z are all of the same length)
Parallel coordinates plot
Quantiles to compare two distributions, x must be numeric, y may be numeric, character, or factor but must have two 'levels'
Quantiles of x with respect to the values expected under a theoretical distribution
Matrix of bivariate plots
Single dimension plot, x must be numeric, y may be a factor
3d surface plot
Bivariate plots (with many functionalities)
Column named 'name'
Column named 'name'
Element of the list named 'name'
Element of the list named 'name'
Nth element of the list
List with elements n
Columns 1 and 3
Column j
Row named 'name'
Row i
Element at row i, column j
Element named 'name'
Elements from n+1 to the end
First n elements
Specific elements
All but the nth element
Nth element
Elements in the given set
Prints the arguments after coercing to character; sep is the character separator between arguments
From internet
Format an R object for pretty printing
Prints its arguments; generic, meaning it can have different methods for different objects
Remote input
Read a vector x
Output to file, until sink()
Run the commands in file
Run the commands in clipboard
Remote input
Angle in radians of the complex number
Complex conjugate
Compute the several kinds of convolutions of two sequences
Covariance between x and y, or between the columns of x and those of y if they are matrices or data frames
A vector which ith element is the maximum from x[1] to x[i]
A vector which ith element is the minimum from x[1] to x[i]
A vector which ith element is the product from x[1] to x[i]
A vector which ith element is the sum from x[1] to x[i]
Lagged and iterated differences of vector x
Fast Fourier Transform of an array
Applies linear filtering to a univariate time series or to each series separately of a multivariate time series
Imaginary part
'set' function
'set' function
Computes the logarithm of x with base base
Maximum of the elements of x
Minimum of the elements of x
Modulus; abs(x) is the same
FFT of each column of a matrix
A vector which ith element is the maximum of x[i], y[i], . . .
A vector which ith element is the minimum of x[i], y[i], . . .
Product of the elements of x
Idem then c(min(x), max(x))
Ranks of the elements of x
Real part of a complex number
Rounds the elements of x to n decimals
If x is a matrix, centers and scales the data; to center only use the option scale=FALSE, to scale only center=FALSE (by default center=TRUE, scale=TRUE)
'set' function
'set' function
Sum of the elements of x
'set' function
Matrix multiplication
Fast version of col means
Sum of cols for a matrix-like object; colSums(x) is a faster version
Fast version of row means
Sum of rows for a matrix-like object; rowSums(x) is a faster version
Matrix inverse of a
Solves a %*% x=b for x
Missing data
Quit R
Set R working folder on 'dir'
Integer divide
Logical negation
Not equals
Elementwise and
Control and
Greater than
Greater than or equal to
Less than
Less than or equal to
Elementwise or
Control or
Elementwise exclusive or
Computes the Akaike information criterion or AIC
Linearly interpolate given data points; x can be an xy plotting structure
Returns the estimated coefficients (sometimes with their standard-errors)
Returns the deviance
Returns the number of residual degrees of freedom
Returns the fitted values

Fit generalized linear models, specified by giving a symbolic description of the linear predictor and a description of the error distribution; family is a description of the error distribution and link function to be used in the model; see ?family
Fit linear models; formula is typically of the form response termA + termB + ...; use I(x*y) + I(x^2) for terms made of nonlinear components
Fit a polynomial surface using local fitting
Computes the logarithm of the likelihood and the number of parameters
Minimize function f using a Newton-type algorithm with starting values p
Nonlinear least-squares estimates of the nonlinear model parameters
General-purpose optimization; par is initial values, fn is function to optimize (normally minimize)
Predictions from fit based on input data
Returns the residuals
Cubic spline interpolation
Splits the data frame x into subsets, computes summary statistics for each, and returns the result in a convenient form; by is a list of grouping elements, each as long as the variables in x
A vector or array or list of values obtained by applying a function FUN to margins (INDEX) of x
Apply FUN to data frame data subsetted by INDEX
Apply FUN to each element of the list x
Merge two data frames by common columns or row names

Reshapes a data frame between 'wide' format with repeated measurements in separate columns of the same record and 'long' format with the repeated measurements in separate records; use (direction='wide') or (direction='long')
Transform data available as separate columns in a data frame or list into a single column
Apply FUN to each cell of a ragged array given by x with indexes INDEX
Inverse of stack()
A contingency table from cross-classifying factors
Example:&&0&&repeat {&& a = a + 1&&&& if (a >= 3) print(a)&& else cat('not\n')&&&& if (a == 10) break&&}
Executes a function call from the name of the function and a list of arguments to be passed to it

Use braces {} around statements.&&&&Example:&&&&0&&for (i in 1:20) {&& a = i&& if(a <= 5 ) {&& cat('a = ', a, '(<= 5)'); cat('\n')&& next&& }&& if(a == 18) {&& cat('a = ', a, '(= 18)'); cat('\n')&& break&& }&&}
Function definition.&&&&Example 1:&&f = function(x) x/10 + 1&&&
Use braces {} around statements.&&&&Example:&&x = 1:9&&for (i in 1:9) {&& if(x[i] <= 5 ) {&& cat('x = ', x[i], '(<= 5)'); cat('\n')&& }&& else {&& cat('x = ', x[i], '(> 5)'); cat('\n')&& }&&}&&
Use braces {} around statements.&&&&Example 1:&&x=1&&if(x != 0) print(x)&&&&Example 2:&&x=1&&if(x != 0) {&& x&& print(x)&&}

A value with the same shape as test filled with elements from either yes or no.&&&&Example 1:&&set.seed(15)&&x = rnorm(10)&&x&&y = ifelse(x > 0, 1, -1)&&y&&&&Example 2:&&z = ifelse(x > 0, 1, ifelse(x < 0, '< zero', 0))&&z

Basic control-flow constructs of the R language.&&&&Example:&&0&&for (i in 1:20) {&& a = i&& if(a <= 5 ) {&& cat('a = ', a, '(<= 5)'); cat('\n')&& next&& }&& if(a == 18) {&& cat('a = ', a, '(= 18)'); cat('\n')&& break&& }&&}&&
Use braces {} around state.&&&&Example:&&0&&repeat {&& a = a + 1&&&& if (a >= 3) print(a)&& else cat('not\n')&&&& if (a == 10) break&&}&&
Optional return of functions.&&&&Example:&&if(x != 0) print(x)&&&&myf = function(a=1, b=2) {&& c = a + b&& return(c)&&}&&&&myf()&&myf(3, 4)&&

switch evaluates a expression and accordingly chooses one of the further arguments &&&&Example:&&set.seed(59)&&x = letters[floor(1 + runif(1, 0, 4))]&&x&&y = switch(x,&& a='Bonjour',&& b='Gutten Tag',&& c='Hello',&& d='Konnichi wa')&&y&&
Use braces {} around statements.&&&&Example:&&0&&while (a < 11) {&& if (a >= 3) print(a)&& else cat('not\n')&& a = a + 1&&}&&

kmeans cluster analysis

Mean of x with weights w

A vector of the positions of first matches for the elements of x among table
Number of characters
Concatenate vectors after converting to character; 'sep=' is the string to separate terms (a single space is the default); 'collapse=' is an optional string to separate 'collapsed' results
Partial matches for the elements of x among table
Split x according to the substring split
Substrings in a character vector; can also assign, as substr(x, start, stop)=value

Get or set the list of attributes of obj
Get or set the class of x; class(x)='myclass'

Print useful information about object
